question: Show that the function $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, defined as $f(x)=x^2$, is neither one-one nor onto.
solution:
Since $f(-1) = 1 = f(1)$, $f$ is not one-one. 

Also, the element $-2$ in the co-domain $\mathbb{R}$ is not image of any element $x$ in the domain $\mathbb{R}$ (Why?). Therefore $f$ is not onto.
